reviews.text: This is the weird sort of film that is, on its own merits, perfectly well produced and entertaining, yet winds up being a slight disappointment because it feels as if it should have been somewhat better than it is.
reviews.author: Grant Watson

reviews.text: Not just a great animated film, but an important one...
reviews.author: Brendan Cassidy

reviews.text: Disney’s Zootopia looks at the ‘otherization’ prevalent at every step of our social structure.
reviews.author: Pradeep Menon

reviews.text: “A well thought out and very witty movie… one for the whole family to enjoy”
reviews.author: Victoria Luxford

reviews.text: With equal measures of animated beauty and socially responsible intelligence, Zootopia stands among Disney's very best.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: It's got all the hallmarks of a great animated movie, and it doesn't fail to get laughs and give you that warm happy feeling that an inspiring film should.
reviews.author: Therese Lacson

reviews.text: Builds a fully realized world, lands almost all its jokes and teaches valuable lessons.
reviews.author: Kip Mooney

reviews.text: I have to be honest and say that I actually liked Zootopia, despite its flaws, and laughed my head off at some parts.
reviews.author: Hosea Rupprecht

reviews.text: The message is an overt one, and they make sure to hammer it home, but it is not a false one.
reviews.author: Michael J. Casey

reviews.text: ...thought provoking and funny. With time, it may actually reveal itself to be genius.
reviews.author: Olly Richards

reviews.text: The abundance of humor and action help to mask all the underlying themes that can be construed as far too adult or mature for the family-friendly layout.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: Zootopia is the rare animated Disney film that feels like it was made for adults almost as much as children.
reviews.author: Danielle Solzman

reviews.text: It's colorful, fun, and has a good message. Will I remember it tomorrow? Probably not, but that doesn't mean I didn't like it today.
reviews.author: Allen Almachar

reviews.text: Zootopia is a spectacular achievement on every level. It's a big, bold adventure in a remarkably rendered universe steeped in popular culture, a touching story of unlikely friendship, and a sharp critique of modern society.
reviews.author: Brent McKnight

reviews.text: The idea of multiculturalism is not acceptance but tolerance[.]
reviews.author: CJ Sheu

reviews.text: Zootopia is your classic reluctant partners buddy cop flick transposed into family-friendly entertainment ... an intelligent animated film that will resonate with children well into their adulthood.
reviews.author: Damond Fudge

reviews.text: As entertainment it is a very funny animated film with the fable of Judy, the new heroine of Disney. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Yasser Medina

reviews.text: It was complex in its message and yet clear.
reviews.author: Avaryl Halley

reviews.text: Totally adorable and cute.
reviews.author: Andrew Galdi

reviews.text: If you only want to view Zootopia as a cheery little feature cartoon, full of the frolicking anthropomorphic critters Disney excels in creating, it works perfectly well on that level...
reviews.author: Kathi Maio

reviews.text: Disney weaves in really important issues interlaced with humor, creativity and fun.
reviews.author: Christie Cronan

reviews.text: Zootopia is one of Disney's best films to date and my favorite film of the year so far. It's family friendly and teaches kids so many great life lessons.
reviews.author: Sarah Knight Adamson

reviews.text: Disney always strove to base his vision of America on the better angels of our nature, and with Zootopia, the company he founded has succeeded.
reviews.author: Chris McCoy

reviews.text: There's so much to see, and so many little touches, that those who fall in love with it upon first viewing, and there will be many, will likely come back over and over.
reviews.author: Leslie Combemale

reviews.text: This is an entertaining piece of original animation and the detail, especially of the animal's hair and fur, is pretty spectacular.
reviews.author: Linda and Al Lerner

reviews.text: Fresh, clever and squeal-level funny, Zootopia was just as brilliant on second viewing and no doubt will be for repeat ad nausea.
reviews.author: Kate Rodger

reviews.text: Like the best animated movies it mixes social subtext with genuinely hilarious moments and interesting characters.
reviews.author: Karl Delossantos

reviews.text: A review eviscerating the film would make as much sense as one praising it, so it comes down to a coin-flip judgment call; let's go with the optimistic view that kids hear "stereotypes and fear of others is bad" and adults reinforce that message.
reviews.author: Ryan Syrek

reviews.text: "Zootopia" includes all the elements of a well-rounded, memorable story that strikes a range of emotional chords. It has lovable characters, witty dialogue, creativity, a great soundtrack and significant themes that resonate with audiences.
reviews.author: Mae Abdulbaki

reviews.text: The world building is remarkable and full of surprises.
reviews.author: Rachel Wagner

reviews.text: Even without the complexity of its message, Zootopia would be a worthwhile addition to the Disney canon; the characters are great, the world is fascinating and the narrative is top-notch.
reviews.author: Allen Adams

reviews.text: Its inspiring and positive message is delivered with infectious humor.
reviews.author: Paula Fleri-Soler

reviews.text: Zootopia is a perfect blend of genres and tones.
reviews.author: Amanda Greever

reviews.text: Imaginatively fresh and very grown-up.
reviews.author: Nathalia Aryani

reviews.text: This is a world that I enjoyed visiting -- and wouldn't mind revisiting sometime in the future.
reviews.author: Micheal Compton

reviews.text: ZOOTOPIA is not a glimmering beacon of light for activists around the world, but it sure is a nice little lesson for everybody to enjoy.
reviews.author: James Clay

reviews.text: Zootopia works masterfully on multiple levels: an enjoyable comedy, a competent detective story, and a reflection of our world with its various complicated problems.
reviews.author: Colby Bryant

reviews.text: Of all the phrases I thought I'd use to describe Zootropolis, I never thought 'socially relevant' would be one of them.
reviews.author: Jennifer Heaton

reviews.text: Pixar has set a high bar for films about anthropomorphized critters, inanimate objects, artificial intelligences and abstract concepts, too high for a harmless but only marginally clever time-filler like Zootopia to fully hurdle.
reviews.author: Daniel Barnes

reviews.text: It just never fully settles into its own message or visual style.
reviews.author: Deirdre Crimmins

reviews.text: Bateman has never been better... His role has what the whole movie has: gumption, grace, charm and intelligence, against the backdrop of a fabulously imaginative world.
reviews.author: Asia Frey

reviews.text: It was so heartwarming and fun that I felt a mighty need to share my feelings about it.
reviews.author: Stephanie Cooke

reviews.text: Sorry Elsa from Frozen, you have been dethroned. The new way adorable queen is a bunny and her name is Judy.
reviews.author: Leah Sydney

reviews.text: Zootopia is actually a thinly-veiled look at diversity... and it's glorious.
reviews.author: Jordan Calhoun

reviews.text: It doesn't sugarcoat how difficult it is to change our ideas of others, but it does suggest how patently stupid many of those ideas are.
reviews.author: Katie Dries

reviews.text: All the film's elements seamlessly converge to relay a timely message that is made even more relevant, given that it seems to be directed to those who will be inheriting a world that seems to foster a culture of hate.
reviews.author: Oggs Cruz

reviews.text: It's surprisingly sophisticated, finding new ways to get us to look past stereotypes.
reviews.author: Eli Glasner

reviews.text: Simply know that when you hear how groundbreaking Zootopia is-the reports are accurate; it just may not all be ground you want to break with your child.
reviews.author: Megan Basham

reviews.text: It's a fun movie...It really hits home with its messaging.
reviews.author: Andre Meadows

reviews.text: Someone needs to break into Donald Trump's home, kidnap him, sit him down in his own personal theater, clamp materials to his eyelids A Clockwork Orange style so they remain open, and play Zootopia on a loop until the themes and messages sink in
reviews.author: Robert Kojder

reviews.text: It's a crazy ride to a world where imagination fuels an entertainment effort like never before.
reviews.author: Rachit Gupta

reviews.text: The animation is stunning, the screenplay as amusing as it is clever, and the voicework -- led by Ginnifer Goodwin, Horrible Bosses star Jason Bateman and our own Idris Elba -- is top-notch.
reviews.author: Matthew Bond

reviews.text: This is a new Disney classic.
reviews.author: Sarah Marrs

reviews.text: The two leads are a great study of how those who have extreme characteristics - and are natural enemies - can be the best of friends if we set aside our fears.
reviews.author: Joanne Soh

reviews.text: Zootopia appears posed to rule the roost with all members of the family as we sprint free of the Oscars.
reviews.author: tt stern-enzi

reviews.text: From the first scene of "Zootopia," Disney's latest animated film, the moral is made clear: to moralize is good, but to bust one's chops is better.
reviews.author: Brooke Corso

reviews.text: This movie is about as good as it gets in the post-Oscar, pre-summer lull. Actually, it's about as good as it gets at the movies all year.
reviews.author: Eleanor Ringel Cater

reviews.text: Like The Lion King, Beauty and the Beast - and yes, Frozen - Zootopia has cemented itself as an instant Disney classic that will be cherished for generations to come.
reviews.author: Julia Alexander

reviews.text: The political landscape from which this film was born is apparent almost from the start, and though at times less than subtle with its agenda, it still manages to be an incredibly witty, emotional and entertaining movie experience.
reviews.author: David Fontana

reviews.text: Do not be perturbed by the animation and animals, this movie is important, intellectual and hilarious.
reviews.author: Alex Casey

reviews.text: Zootopia is a bouncy, candy-colored animation, not an overt political allegory, yet it's an apt movie for this primary season.
reviews.author: Margot Harrison

reviews.text: The detective story is actually engaging. It's simple enough to follow (for kids) but complicated enough to offer both genuine surprises and silly amusing detours.
reviews.author: Nathaniel Rogers

reviews.text: Perfect school holiday entertainment for the whole family.
reviews.author: James Croot

reviews.text: Much of Zootopia's charm results from its wonderful animation and captivating energy, but at heart it's the witty, insightful script around deeper socio-political issues which makes it truly satisfying for any grown-up who goes to see it.
reviews.author: Sarah Watt

reviews.text: A smart four-footed spin on the buddy-cop genre.
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: Sure to speak to kids and grown-ups alike, Zooptopia unfolds a poignant lesson about how prejudice can hurt people, but also how it can be overcome. And it does all this in a wonderfully fun film.
reviews.author: Kristy Puchko

reviews.text: Zootopia is a reminder of just how beautiful animated films can be. Holy cow, this thing is almost hallucinatory.
reviews.author: Drew McWeeny

reviews.text: Zootopia is an exceptional film and -- dare I say it? -- an important one.
reviews.author: Petra Halbur

reviews.text: There are enough under-the-radar subtleties, rendered with a refreshing lack of smart-aleckiness, to make Zootopia feel current and fresh. It's a modest, unassuming entertainment that's motored by a sly sensibility.
reviews.author: Stephanie Zacharek

reviews.text: Zootopia has great voice performances from Ginnifer Goodwin and Jason Bateman who suit their characters perfectly.
reviews.author: Soumya Srivastava

reviews.text: Zootopia is a blast to watch, a wonderful cartoon experience with an extra bit of gravitas for spice and flavor.
reviews.author: Bill Gibron

reviews.text: The film's messages -- the importance of tolerance and following your dreams -- are pretty standard for a kiddie flick. But there's a political edge that is very unusual for a Disney movie.
reviews.author: Andy Lea

reviews.text: An entertaining and endlessly inventive comedy and something with more insight than anyone could have anticipated.
reviews.author: Jamie Neish

reviews.text: [A] colorful, nicely crafted, perfectly voice-cast animated feature.
reviews.author: Melissa Starker

reviews.text: Charming and inventive.
reviews.author: Camilla Long

reviews.text: Not only does [Zootopia] have a strong plot but also a fantastic message of tolerance and inclusion for audiences of all ages.
reviews.author: Tom Crowley

reviews.text: Directors Byron Howard, Rich Moore and Jared Bush do a fine job of keeping Zootopia amusing for kids and equally enjoyable for the adults who accompany them to theaters.
reviews.author: Robert Denerstein

reviews.text: In its attempt to please both children and adults equally, Zootopia is a failure.
reviews.author: Christopher Schobert

reviews.text: ...a genuinely charming and funny film.
reviews.author: Josh Spiegel

reviews.text: The [DMV} sequence is so funny that it's oddly forgivable that the rest of Zootopia rarely matches up to that comic plateau.
reviews.author: Dan Lybarger

reviews.text: ...an Animal Farm-type fable about racism and sexism -- a shrewd and timely critique of fear-based politics set in a remarkably detailed, endlessly fascinating alternate universe.
reviews.author: Philip Martin

reviews.text: One of Disney's best movies in past years. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fico Cangiano

reviews.text: It's a total hoot.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: Zootopia pulls together various elements - a neo-noir mystery, a buddy-cop comedy, and timely social themes - into a mostly entertaining animated film.
reviews.author: Roxana Hadadi

reviews.text: Using the animal kingdom as a means to convey so much sense about our own contemporary world is a masterstroke which owes a debt to George Orwell.
reviews.author: Ben Rawson-Jones

reviews.text: Behind the gaze of an optimistic and inclusive film, we have a great homage to the hard-boiled film noir of the 1940s. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Alejandro Alemán

reviews.text: It is much too willing to abandon boundless creativity to wallow in an endless succession of overfamiliar narrative constraints. But at the same time, it uses those constraints generally quite well.
reviews.author: Tim Brayton

reviews.text: A perfect embodiment of the kind of fable Aesop used to tell.
reviews.author: Wesley Lovell

reviews.text: a fast and funny fable about the need for tolerance and understanding in a world in which fear and prejudice are more convenient
reviews.author: James Kendrick

reviews.text: Another stellar Disney film that begs for a second look thanks to its evocative overtones and commentary.
reviews.author: Felix Vasquez Jr.

reviews.text: For all the animal antics on display here, the movie also gently broaches all-too-human issues of stereotyping, prejudice and racism. This is something worthwhile to chew over, even for younger audiences.
reviews.author: Boon Chan

reviews.text: The dazzling design of Zootopia offers a non-stop stream of invention and visual wit that perfectly enhances a surprisingly involving plot...A gleaming gem of a film.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: There's plenty of charm and a decent plot to keep things moving.
reviews.author: Harry Guerin

reviews.text: ... a deceptively clever movie that has timely lessons for all generational demographics.
reviews.author: David Crow

reviews.text: Zootopia tucks a message of tolerance for other species (and races and creeds) into a cheerfully anthropomorphised view of the animal kingdom.
reviews.author: Nandini Ramnath

reviews.text: Zootopia remembers the power of George Orwell's Animal Farm and gives it a Disney digital system upgrade and brings it to the 21st Century.
reviews.author: Blake Howard

reviews.text: Believe it: Disney's latest digitally animated feature is a contra-Trumpian, race-conscious, political-conspiracy neo-noir in the guise of a funny talking-animal cartoon.
reviews.author: John Beifuss

reviews.text: "Zootopia" is a vibrant and smart movie... at times, though, it feels more like commercial compromise than the distinctive art of superior animated works.
reviews.author: John Serba

reviews.text: If the film is superficially great, a plastered-over screenplay lurks just beneath, poking its ugly head out early and often.
reviews.author: J. Olson

reviews.text: What's so clever about Zootopia is it takes the normal feel-good positive messages, this time about not judging people by their sex or race, and mixes it with something more mature, a vintage Los Angeles-like crime noir.
reviews.author: Francesca Rudkin

reviews.text: This is the best animated film I've seen since 'The Incredibles.'
reviews.author: Robert Roten

reviews.text: 'Zootopia' is a brilliant, funny story about bias, empowerment and understanding. And oh, how it entertains while it tells the tale
reviews.author: Linda Cook

reviews.text: Although it would be stretching things to describe Zootopia as a metaphor for modern society, its underlying message of racial tolerance is a useful lesson for everyone.
reviews.author: Richard James Havis

reviews.text: Zootopia is the best Disney animated movie, either with Pixar or without it, since Toy Story 3 in 2010.
reviews.author: Mahmoud Mahdy

reviews.text: It's a bunny movie ... sorry, a buddy movie ... in family-fun land, where the rookie cop (a bunny) has to team up with a small-time crim (a fox) to track down bigger crooks. Anthropomorphic as it is, there is plenty of innocent fun
reviews.author: Andrew L. Urban

reviews.text: It's a gorgeous film beautifully executed with a story that will have you smiling throughout. Don't miss it!
reviews.author: Louise Keller

reviews.text: Zootopia, like its protagonist, walks blissfully into a jungle of discourse it has precious little chance of surviving.
reviews.author: Dominic Barlow

reviews.text: Done with creativity and wit ... but still has the stridency of a lesson plan.
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: How refreshing it is to see an animated movie that takes the initiative to climb above the restrictions of its formula.
reviews.author: David Keyes

reviews.text: The genius of the film lies in its combination of traditional Disney characters and situations with a very subversive storytelling style.
reviews.author: Geoffrey Macnab

reviews.text: The filmmakers behind Tangled and Wreck-it Ralph join forces for this entertaining animated action comedy, which has clearly been planned as a franchise-launcher.
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: It is its own cinematic zooniverse.
reviews.author: Ali Gray

reviews.text: You may be taken aback by just how good it really is.
reviews.author: Peter Sobczynski

reviews.text: ...manages an incredible balancing act having fun with their high concept while taking nothing away from the seriousness of their story. Prejudice 101 - for kids of all ages.
reviews.author: Kevin A. Ranson

reviews.text: Clever, funny and refreshingly bold, its message is endearing and engaging, without falling into sentimentality.
reviews.author: Marija Djurovic

reviews.text: A pretty sophisticated meditation on race relations dressed up as a delightfully entertaining, gag-packed and inventively plotted police procedural.
reviews.author: Alistair Harkness

reviews.text: The film feels like a riposte to Trump-ism. It also contains some of the best sloth-related humour you will ever see.
reviews.author: Charlotte O'Sullivan

reviews.text: Here's a great-looking, emotionally engaging and enormously entertaining movie guaranteed to delight kids and adults alike.
reviews.author: David Edwards

reviews.text: The latest Disney animated feature may not be a classic but it is full of bright ideas and funny one-liners.
reviews.author: Allan Hunter

reviews.text: The friendship between predator and prey stands as a powerful rebuke to Donald Trump.
reviews.author: Henry Fitzherbert

reviews.text: An encouragingly upbeat celebration of love and diversity in times of hate and uncertainty.
reviews.author: Mark Kermode

reviews.text: The illness in our society comes from the artificial stratification, and defensive denial, of original difference.
reviews.author: Walter Chaw

reviews.text: Cute and clever in equal measure.
reviews.author: Jason Best

reviews.text: The voice cast is perfect - especially Bateman - and there are some cracking action scenes too. Superb family film.
reviews.author: Alex Zane

reviews.text: An animated outing that propels Disney's historical success at anthropomorphisation to new heights.
reviews.author: Tim Evans

reviews.text: The animation is first rate - fur is rendered so realistically that it could trigger an allergy at 50 paces - but it is the writing that elevates the picture.
reviews.author: Wendy Ide

reviews.text: There's rarely been so much sub in the text of an animated movie, and while it makes Zootopia a surprisingly thought provoking experience, there's also something slightly disconcerting about Disney's willingness to so keenly embrace adult themes.
reviews.author: Erin Free

reviews.text: There's a magical moment in every movie of quality, a reciprocal bond between screen and viewer, where your shoulders happily drop, you sink deeper into your seat and your soul secretly smiles because it knows that you are in the safest of hands.
reviews.author: Kevin Maher

reviews.text: It's easy to see why the studio is back at the top of its game and proves its still the master of producing films both children and adults will engage with.
reviews.author: Amy West

reviews.text: For the young and innocent minded, there's plenty of knockabout fun and slapstick humour to enjoy, coupled with a timely message about tolerance and integration, while pop culture references abound for adults and film fans to savour.
reviews.author: Rob Carnevale

reviews.text: The fictional universe it presents - a human-free world where mammals have evolved into a bustling, civilised society - is vividly realised, richly detailed and very funny.
reviews.author: John Nugent

reviews.text: One of the film's great strengths is the trust it puts in its young audience to decode its complex, nuanced message about the value of difference.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: Marvelous. A bouncy comedy mystery adventure parable in a fantasy world meticulously and cleverly conceived and gorgeously realized. I adore this movie.
reviews.author: MaryAnn Johanson

reviews.text: This has enough light wit and gooey sentiment for Disney groupies, and yet it does leave many unanswered questions.
reviews.author: David 'Mad Dog' Bradley

reviews.text: It acknowledges problems that no bumper-sticker can patch over, and yet it leaves room for an exploration of a seriously charming world.
reviews.author: Richard von Busack

reviews.text: The voice cast are all on enjoyable form, and the storyline, once it kicks into gear, is not simply a vehicle for the message of the film, but an enjoyable caper in its own right, full of motion and invention.
reviews.author: Martin Roberts

reviews.text: Just relish the zingy jokes and in-jokes; a slow-burn dialogue scene with sloths that's an instant classic; the elastic character animation; and the pacy, racy disrespect for PC of all hues and flavours.
reviews.author: Nigel Andrews

reviews.text: Directors Byron Howard and Rich Moore have crafted this environment in a meticulous fashion, with a striking attention to detail, painting a comprehensive picture of this universe we're inhabiting.
reviews.author: Stefan Pape

reviews.text: The film gracefully deals with the contradiction between what we feel, who we are and what we let other people see. [Full review in Portuguese.]
reviews.author: Pablo Villaça

reviews.text: Zootropolis takes the form of a jovial noir thriller, is nicely voiced by the likes of Jason Bateman and Ginnifer Goodwin and should go down very well with the smaller viewer.
reviews.author: Paul Whitington

reviews.text: Bright and mostly brilliant.
reviews.author: Aine O'Connor

reviews.text: No instant Disney classic, but a fast and furry-ious caper with endless gags, a fizzy fox-bunny double act and Shakira as a singing gazelle.
reviews.author: Neil Smith

reviews.text: It's a delight. Don't miss it.
reviews.author: Jean Lowerison

reviews.text: Stepping back from the movie's key themes, the creative team behind the project deserve praise for crafting a fun, complex world.
reviews.author: Matthew Toomey

reviews.text: Much like George Orwell used animals as an allegory for communism and social inequality, Disney has used Zootopia to deliver a story about prejudice and intolerance.
reviews.author: Tim Martain

reviews.text: A lively and universally accessible story is set in an idealised, human-free future where animals of all species have learned to live as one.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: Threatens to blow away Shane Black's The Nice Guys for Best Buddy-Cop Film of 2016.
reviews.author: Liam Maguren

reviews.text: Zootropolis has a plot you can really, ahem, sink teeth into.
reviews.author: Donald Clarke

reviews.text: Wildly entertaining.
reviews.author: Michael Smith

reviews.text: A surprisingly sharp examination of racial profiling, prejudice, equality and stereotyping, and how often can you say that about a kids movie?
reviews.author: Matt Neal

reviews.text: I mean, come on -- what was the last kids film that stumbled because it was overreaching in its exploration of inclusiveness? Also -- those sloths!
reviews.author: Matt Roden

reviews.text: The tale of a plucky rabbit and a sly fox, it's also a meditation on human nature, civil society and the politics of stereotyping. And it has great sloth jokes.
reviews.author: Philippa Hawker

reviews.text: In this zippy and entertaining children's animation that comes with an unusually thoughtful commentary on inclusion and discrimination, the animals don't just come out in the city at night, they literally run it during the day.
reviews.author: Craig Mathieson

reviews.text: A well balanced film with a powerful message and a great story. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fausto Ponce

reviews.text: Gorgeous to look at, clever, funny and with a solid and atmospheric mystery at its core. But there's more here in the film's timely and relevant thematic content.
reviews.author: Ken Hanke

reviews.text: Impressionable kids and adults who swear they're progressive will both take something away from Zootopia.
reviews.author: Matt Patches

reviews.text: Zootopia excels on so many levels that it stands with the finest of the Disney classics.
reviews.author: Lou Lumenick

reviews.text: Not many animated films give adults, teenagers and adults something to enjoy and that doesn't fall into the dumb humor territory. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Cuauhtémoc Ruelas

reviews.text: Reminiscent of "Toy Story" in its ability to create a wonderfully colorful world of its own, "Zootopia" is a fun film with undeniably important themes about diversity, inclusion and self-worth.
reviews.author: John Hanlon

reviews.text: A spunky 3-D animated film about a bunny whose life is energized by big dreams and rock-solid optimism.
reviews.author: Frederic and Mary Ann Brussat

reviews.text: It is complex, different, thinking, technically flawless and definitely a fun Disney product that works the same for children and adults. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Edgardo Reséndiz

reviews.text: By using animation the movie gives a snapshot of the problems of intolerance that live in the world, without leaving aside the humor. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Eduardo Molina

reviews.text: Exciting visuals, good characters, lots of laughs and even a timely allegory about American race relations. (Splice Today)
reviews.author: Stephen Silver

reviews.text: "Zootopia," like its heroine, is zesty, bright, and breakneck, with chase scenes and well-tuned gags where you half expect songs to be.
reviews.author: Anthony Lane

reviews.text: The Mouse House may win the gold for Best Animated Feature in 2017 for this intrepid, action-packed comedy/police procedural parable.
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: There's a lot here for kids to like and nearly as much to keep parents from fidgeting.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: Timely message buoys charming, clever "Zootopia."
reviews.author: Charles Koplinski

reviews.text: In many ways a conventional movie, but it unfolds with so much wit, panache, and visual ingenuity that it outstrips many a more high-concept film.
reviews.author: Christopher Orr

reviews.text: From the enormity of the world building, the slick animation, the enthusiastic voice work done by a sprawling cast and a script that's intelligent and warm, Zootopia is already shaping up to be a highlight of the 2016 cinematic year.
reviews.author: Allyson Johnson

reviews.text: What an unexpected surprise, a Disney animation with Orwellian anthropomorphic political allegory and a film noir backdrop not seen since Roger Rabbit was framed.
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: It should serve as a terrific inspiration for little girls to dream big and aspire high. But the larger message "Zootopia" is sending is one of tolerance and understanding.
reviews.author: Al Alexander

reviews.text: Sure to become a classic.
reviews.author: Jeanne Kaplan

reviews.text: A movie you will tell your friends and family about.
reviews.author: David Kaplan

reviews.text: Zootopia is a great animated film, but it might be something much more: a clarion call for sanity and understanding arriving just when we need it the most.
reviews.author: Rob Vaux

reviews.text: This 3D animated comedy has the expected combination of kid-friendly slapstick and pop-culture send-ups, but underneath that slick surface it promotes a message of tolerance and empowerment.
reviews.author: Todd Jorgenson

reviews.text: What saves this big-budget cartoon behemoth is its modest, old-fashioned storytelling.
reviews.author: David Edelstein

reviews.text: With this film Disney has a truly progressive jump with a character who achieves the seemingly impossible by his willpower and intelligence. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Juanma Fernández París

reviews.text: Zootopia is to 2016 what Inside Out was to 2015 - a next-level animated feature that gives kids something of substance while simultaneously showing them a really good time.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: The comic high point is a scene at the DMV where sloths work behind the counter and talk. Very. Very. Very. Slowly. If the movie is overlong because of that one hilarious scene, it was worth it.
reviews.author: Robert Horton

reviews.text: Disarming characters... multidimensional plot form the core of an atypical Disney movie that's right on the mark...
reviews.author: Leonard Maltin

reviews.text: Unlike a certain Pixar property having to do with automobiles, this one warrants a sequel.
reviews.author: Randall King

reviews.text: A rich blend of story, message and entertainment.
reviews.author: Josh Terry

reviews.text: It's confusing when it starts to feel that Zootopia is working against its own message to get easy laughs.
reviews.author: Scott Renshaw

reviews.text: Zootopia is filled with lovable characters and a heartfelt message for kids - along with a layered subtext for adults that is both timely and moving.
reviews.author: Ben Kendrick

reviews.text: A funny, beautifully designed kids' film with a message that it restates at every turn.
reviews.author: Matt Zoller Seitz

reviews.text: Don't be surprised if Zootopia ends up becoming a kids' detective series, based on how fabulously these two go about working the case.
reviews.author: Alynda Wheat

reviews.text: The script is highly entertaining - funny enough to keep the young ones entertained, but witty enough to keep adults hooked and LOL-ing through most of the movie.
reviews.author: Latoya Newman

reviews.text: The cagey and delightful 'Zootopia' is creature comfort in every way.
reviews.author: Roger Tennis

reviews.text: Somehow, Disney has managed to pull off a hard-boiled police procedural thriller about political corruption starring an adorable, large-eyed bunny. As strange as this combination might seem, it works. Who knew bunnies could make such intrepid rookie cops?
reviews.author: Katie Walsh

reviews.text: A buddy-cop comedy crossed with a political thriller and mashed up against a social drama. It's a credit to Disney's collaborative process that the whole thing manages to hold together as well as it does.
reviews.author: Matthew Lickona

reviews.text: Teems with sight gags and puns and pop culture references, but it's all an excuse to use the buddy cop genre they way it was always intended, as a form of social commentary.
reviews.author: William Bibbiani

reviews.text: The computer-generated creatures have smooth and cheerful lines, like old-style "stretch-and-squash" animation. The movie is wonderfully fluid and graceful.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: The motor vehicles department scene alone is worth the price of a ticket. I'm still laughing.
reviews.author: Gary Wolcott

reviews.text: It's the best film so far of 2016 and should easily be at or near the top of the list for Best Animated Film come award season next December and beyond. (Full Content Review for Parents - Violence, Scary Stuff, etc. - Also Available)
reviews.author: Jim Judy

reviews.text: Shows just how far the House of Mouse has evolved from dreamy prince-and-princess fairy tales of decades past.
reviews.author: Neil Pond

reviews.text: [I]t's dealing head-on -- in that subversively indirect way that these animal-based tales do -- with issues that aren't so easily defined and are far more difficult to resolve.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: "Zootopia" is a wolf in sheep's clothing, a movie packed with talking animals that dares to be something more by offering up a bold little slice of social commentary.
reviews.author: Mathew DeKinder

reviews.text: Charming buddy-animal story promotes tolerance, teamwork.
reviews.author: Sandie Angulo Chen

reviews.text: If Zootopia becomes fortunate enough to fall into Frozen-style heavy rotation for kids of a certain age, its messages of rejecting prejudice and embracing the complicated nature of multiculturalism could do some good for the world.
reviews.author: Andrew Lapin

reviews.text: Credit the Disney folks with making what could have been a lecture on stereotypes into one of the more amusing animated kidflicks of recent vintage.
reviews.author: Bob Mondello

reviews.text: Even though Zootopia remains whimsical family entertainment and never turns into a polemic, at its core it has more in common with Animal Farm . . . than it does with other classic anthropomorphized Disney fare . . .
reviews.author: Violet LeVoit

reviews.text: It's a candy-coated film that doesn't sugar-coat the complexities of race relations.
reviews.author: Rob Thomas

reviews.text: Lions and tigers and preconceived notions about others based on their outward appearances ... oh my!
reviews.author: Christian Toto

reviews.text: Leaving aside amusing jokes about the wolves trying desperately to contain a group howl or sloths working as bureaucrats, animal behaviour is a troubling metaphor for cultural diversity.
reviews.author: Kate Taylor

reviews.text: ...a decidedly middle-of-the-road Disney effort...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: "Zootopia" is a delight: It's cute and clever, smart and sophisticated, with plenty to offer children and adults.
reviews.author: Adam Graham

reviews.text: Donald Trump would scream 'loser' were he to see Disney's 'Zootopia.'
reviews.author: Kirk Honeycutt

reviews.text: Kids will undoubtedly enjoy it, but this one seems meant more for adults who can appreciate its ingeniously fabricated world and its big-hearted ideals.
reviews.author: Eric D. Snider

reviews.text: A winning combination of comedy, drama, suspense and thrills that will delight kids and adults alike. It's a potent reminder that we're in a Golden Age of Animation.
reviews.author: Avi Offer

reviews.text: Disney's 'Zootopia' is wildly adventurous and knockdown funny, arguably the best film of 2016 so far.
reviews.author: Julian Roman

reviews.text: [Zootopia is] incredibly entertaining in the beginning as we see how different animals live in different parts of Zootopia that feel very human, indeed... It's the dark middle part that is hard to reconcile in a Disney movie.
reviews.author: Nicole Villalpando

reviews.text: Simple though its politics may be, the film is effective -- and coming from a mainstream studio, it is even just daring enough to make a difference.
reviews.author: Andy Crump

reviews.text: Everything you could want in an animated film: creative visuals, solid script, engaging characters.
reviews.author: Daniel M. Kimmel

reviews.text: An agreeable hodgepodge, at least, one that aims to be not just a breezy mystery, but also a race-and-ethnicity fable.
reviews.author: Tom Russo

reviews.text: Zootopia is Yootopia if you're looking for jaunty fun.
reviews.author: Joe Morgenstern

reviews.text: Bursting with a rich blend of timely themes, superb voice work, wonderful visuals and laugh-out-loud wit, Walt Disney Animation Studios' "Zootopia" is quite simply a great time at the movies.
reviews.author: Gary Goldstein

reviews.text: These filmmakers cross-fertilize social satire with burlesque, parody, and self-parody.
reviews.author: Michael Sragow

reviews.text: It's got a catchy pop song and a nice message about working to achieve your dreams. But because the directors pushed further- in showing how prejudice seeps into our daily lives-they've made Zootopia a destination you absolutely must visit.
reviews.author: Matt Goldberg

reviews.text: This charming, pop culture soaked movie admirably takes on racial issues but sags under the weight of its muddled metaphors.
reviews.author: Devin Faraci

reviews.text: Apart from its anthropomorphic, allegorical angle, Zootopia is also a tale of female empowerment and a classic noir, too.
reviews.author: Steven Rea

reviews.text: Disney's latest is clever and endearing, but it's the animated equivalent of a pro-diversity pep rally.
reviews.author: Loey Lockerby

reviews.text: Ginnifer Goodwin and Jason Bateman lead an aces voice cast, playing good-cop bunny Judy Hopps and con-artist fox Nick Wilde, who must find common turf to solve a crime wave in the title metropolis. Call it fur noir.
reviews.author: Peter Howell

reviews.text: A winning, gorgeously animated story about anthropomorphic animals living in relative harmony in a bustling metropolis.
reviews.author: Josh Bell

reviews.text: Disney's Zootopia is sweet and addresses social issues with sensitivity. Sometimes it can't quite reach its lofty goals, but it's still wildly entertaining.
reviews.author: Alan Cerny

reviews.text: An indication of what good animation can do in the service of a decent story.
reviews.author: Chris Knight

reviews.text: This one's both intelligent and endearing.
reviews.author: Reagan Gavin Rasquinha

reviews.text: The result is a slam-dunk candidate for best animated feature in next year's Oscars. But the pleasure now comes in appreciating the sumptuous artistry.
reviews.author: Bruce Kirkland

reviews.text: It's hard to create wonder with animation these days, but with its mix of the detailed storybook, the 3-D stuffy, and the retro-Disney cartoon, Zootopia conjures an animal kingdom that still manages to astonish.
reviews.author: Janet Smith

reviews.text: In addition to being a crowd-pleasing Disney cartoon, Byron Howard and Rich Moore's Zootopia works as both a nifty detective story and a parable on institutionalized racism.
reviews.author: Sherilyn Connelly

reviews.text: A clever piece of family entertainment that wittily uses whodunit convention to deliver messages about tolerance, self-confidence and friendship in eye-catching fashion.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: Zootopia might not be the best of Disney's recent in-house movies, but it's easily the most political film the Mouse House has turned out in a good while.
reviews.author: Dominick Suzanne-Mayer

reviews.text: Zootropolis is a colourful, creative and charming film, full of wit and invention.
reviews.author: James Mottram

reviews.text: It strikes a near perfect balance between fun family comedy and message film, never feeling like it's too much of either.
reviews.author: Britton Peele

reviews.text: It's smart entertainment that deals effectively with issues of diversity and sexism, while staying light and never preachy.
reviews.author: Sarah Bryan Miller

reviews.text: Easily one of Disney's more imaginative and detail-oriented CGI offerings in a while, Zootopia uses the classic tropes of anthropomorphized animals and comic references to pop-culture touchstones to slyly puzzle out what it means to be "civilized."
reviews.author: Marc Savlov

reviews.text: The best animated film of the year, as well as one that conveys a message rarely heard in movies for children: Getting exactly what you hoped for isn't the end of the journey.
reviews.author: Jen Chaney

reviews.text: Zootopia is an on-point commentary about prejudice and racism... [and] it explains these subjects to children better than most parents ever could.
reviews.author: David Medsker

reviews.text: An anthropomorphized hippopotamus in a business suit will always be welcome.
reviews.author: Jordan Hoffman

reviews.text: It may lack the bold, pioneering spirit of Disney and Pixar's best animated features, but it still clears some pretty high bars into the human heart.
reviews.author: Barbara VanDenburgh

reviews.text: This animated crime caper comes ready to party hard, but also takes a deep dive when necessary, especially when certain species are treated as threats and cause public panic. Listen up, Mr. Trump.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: On the surface, Zootopia is a witty, wondrous buddy-cop film... At a deeper level, the film allows parents to bring tough topics to the dining-room table, topics such as bullying, stereotyping and inclusiveness.
reviews.author: Maricar Estrella

reviews.text: Funny, smart, thought-provoking - and musical, too.
reviews.author: Neil Genzlinger

reviews.text: Combining a surprisingly sophisticated conspiracy subplot ... with unexpected plot twists, insightful character studies, energetic pacing and even a very funny riff on "The Godfather," "Zootopia" has plenty to appeal to both kids and adults.
reviews.author: Soren Andersen

reviews.text: A mixed bag when it comes to entertainment value, but for the first time in a long time, Disney's attempting a high wire act with tone and content, making the feature intriguing but not always triumphant.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: Zootopia isn't tied down to any specific element in our present-day environment, but nevertheless it emerges as chillingly relevant to our time.
reviews.author: Kristian M. Lin

reviews.text: This wild and comic political twist on "Animal Farm" works for both kids and adults as a reaffirmation of equal justice and opportunity while rejecting racial and gender stereotyping.
reviews.author: Dann Gire

reviews.text: When the new animated movie focuses on the critters, it's a funny trip through the animal kingdom. What slows the ark (oops, make that arc) of the film is a crime story that's in need of a few more monkeyshines.
reviews.author: Rick Bentley

reviews.text: It's a world in which race does not exist. But species certainly do, and they provide a fuzzier, cuddlier way for Zootopia to get at some thorny issues of prejudice and profiling.
reviews.author: Alison Willmore

reviews.text: Zootopia is one of my favorite animated movies. Not one of my favorite animated movies of the last year or two, or of the last decade, or in recent memory. It's one of my favorite animated movies, period.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: It's goofy and joyful. It has an actual message that it's not shy about expressing directly, one that's filled with depth beyond "be nice to each other." And its screenplay is surprisingly clever on a structural level.
reviews.author: Emily St. James

reviews.text: Yes, the adorable factor is pretty high. But so is the movie's IQ. Zootopia is a thought-provoking film about big ideas like tolerance and diversity and rising above your base animal nature.
reviews.author: Laura DeMarco

reviews.text: With "Zootopia" Disney has a new classic on their hands, one that combines memorable characters, gorgeous animation, social awareness, and a framework that can be built upon for years to come.
reviews.author: Travis Hopson

reviews.text: Zootopia is a lot of things at once, and all of them are pretty good.
reviews.author: Norman Wilner

reviews.text: Good intentions don't always make for good movies. Case in point: Zootopia, a Disney film with more on its mind than animated fun and fuzzies. So much, in fact, that it loses track of what audiences expect, what they're being sold.
reviews.author: Steve Persall

reviews.text: Each bustling frame is packed with so much repeated-viewings-rewarded imagery that the screen must be sampled rather than taken in as a whole.
reviews.author: Mick LaSalle

reviews.text: Entertaining and thought-provoking.
reviews.author: Rafer Guzman

reviews.text: Zootopia is stuffed with characters, situations, culture clashes and eye candy.
reviews.author: Edward Johnson-Ott

reviews.text: Wonderfully imagined -- the animators have a lot of fun with the drastic scale and biome differences.
reviews.author: Nell Minow

reviews.text: If you were raised on Zoobooks and Far Side cartoons, ZOOTOPIA is one of the greatest animated movies ever.
reviews.author: Vincent Mancini

reviews.text: With a deep, complex yet accessible storyline married to a visually sumptuous telling of an animal tale, the film is an absolute treat, feeling the equal of any classic Disney flick.
reviews.author: Jason Gorber

reviews.text: By investigating the mechanics of long-held cartoon assumptions (both about the harmoniousness of some cartoon animals, and the characteristics of others), Disney is encouraging viewers young and old to see the world differently and more thoughtfully.
reviews.author: Jesse Hassenger

reviews.text: The film goes deeper in its allegorizing, tapping into the volatile nature of identity politics.
reviews.author: Kenji Fujishima

reviews.text: Bright-eyed and bushy-tailed as its long-eared lead while still brilliantly conscious of social issues, Zootopia represents Disney at its most visually resplendent and thematically ambitious.
reviews.author: Isaac Feldberg

reviews.text: Vividly mounted with a breadth of vision worth celebrating. Disney has hit a home run with "Zootopia," a grand entertainment with an ingeniously developed, socially conscious message.
reviews.author: Dustin Putman

reviews.text: Its earnest "You can be anything!" message is heavy-handedly clear, though Zootopia works best as a funny romp that ingeniously imagines a landscape where hamsters can be businessmen and polar bears are the coolest bodyguards around.
reviews.author: Brian Truitt

reviews.text: Zootopia is a wonderful example of how Disney, at its best, can mix its past and present together in a very cool, compelling way.
reviews.author: Eric Goldman

reviews.text: Right there with the likes of "Up" and "Inside Out," "Zootopia" is so well done I forgot it was animated.
reviews.author: Katherine Pushkar

reviews.text: A film with lots of strong ideas that are much needed in times where xenofobia is still a thing. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Israel Acosta Aroche

reviews.text: "Zootopia" dishes its messages the best way possible: colorfully, cleverly, warmly and with humor, all packaged in a strong storyline. It's not among the animated greats, but close enough to certainly be worth a couple hours of a parent's time.
reviews.author: Tony Hicks

reviews.text: A big, sometimes messy, sometimes insightful exploration of bigotry, using animals to preach for a more evolved understanding of each other's innate differences.
reviews.author: Matt Prigge

reviews.text: If Zootopia only reluctantly comes around to its crime-solving story, that's understandable: the good stuff resides in the characterizations and the morality play around them, decrying fear of the other.
reviews.author: Peter Canavese

reviews.text: Zootopia proves a successful amalgamation of disparate influences, much like its eponymous city.
reviews.author: Josh Slater-Williams

reviews.text: Heavy with pop allusions and references to other crime underworld movies, including The Godfather and Chinatown, Zootopia is impressive in its visual conception and scope: At once straightforward and densely layered with wit and incident ...
reviews.author: Michelle Orange

reviews.text: Zootopia's message of tolerance is a noble one. But it's loopy moments ... that give this modest film its magic.
reviews.author: Chris Nashawaty

reviews.text: "A very clever movie with the sort of meticulous world building that's ripe for the spawning of inventive humor."
reviews.author: Christopher Campbell

reviews.text: Delightful Disney animated tale of a city populated by "civilized" animals of all stripes is both fun for kids and a clever mélange of noir and social commentary.
reviews.author: Kevin Lally

reviews.text: A neo-noir buddy cop comedy that will likely entertain children and adults alike thanks to a steady stream of gags and vibrant visuals.
reviews.author: Michael Jaconelli

reviews.text: It has the quality seal of all Disney films, but stands out because of the details. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Diana Sánchez Uranga

reviews.text: It's deffinately not this year's greates animated picture, but it's one that works and it works good. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ernesto Diezmartinez

reviews.text: The world that Zootropolis creates is intelligent and fascinatingly detailed -- it feels more like a movie by Disney-owned Pixar than a straight Disney film.
reviews.author: Dave Calhoun

reviews.text: The most ingenious part of the film is building this designed and raised city for animals, creating the perfect metaphor about how a rabbit and a mouse can represent our dreams, ambitions, talents and flaws. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Mario P. Székely

reviews.text: Zootopia isn't simply another fun Disney animated movie. It's one of the greatest Disney animated movies the company has ever produced.
reviews.author: Dirk Libbey

reviews.text: A solid job with its own message that can be enjoyed from different views. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Uriel Barco

reviews.text: Disney created a fun fable, as smart as a dolphin, quick as a hare and with a message as strong as a bull. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Adrián Ruiz

reviews.text: Zootopia makes a statement about how we should not judge people by race, genre or looks. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Carolina Ruiz

reviews.text: Zootopia has all the elements to become a classic for fans of the House of Mouse. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jonathan Sánchez

reviews.text: It's funny, it's clever, it's exciting and suspenseful, and it operates as one of the more potent "social issues" pictures that we've seen from a major studio (even during the Oscar season) in quite some time.
reviews.author: Scott Mendelson

reviews.text: A wild ride with some noir-ish undertones, Zootropolis packs in plenty to keep the whole family entertained.
reviews.author: Peter Turner

reviews.text: A smart play on "the race card" in this fun and politically correct Disney film. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Pablo O. Scholz

reviews.text: Zootopia continues the wining streak Disney has had since Tangled. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Sergio Benítez

reviews.text: The be-true-to-yourself and don't-judge-others messages are nicely worked in: while it's robustly right-on, including being cheerfully feminist, it never feels preachy.
reviews.author: Emma Simmonds

reviews.text: A noir comedy that carries itself with loads of imagination. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jordi Costa

reviews.text: The variety of cute - and occasionally slightly scary - animals should keep younger kids interested for most of the hour-and-three-quarters running time, while older kids and parents will be diverted by the comedy and pop culture references.
reviews.author: John Hazelton

reviews.text: Zootopia is a big surprise that offers quality fun creating an interesting story that keeps you interested until the end. [Full Review in spanish]
reviews.author: Mikel Zorrilla

reviews.text: Just when it was looking like animated animal movies had run out of anything original to say, along comes the smartly amusing, crisply relevant Zootopia to handily demonstrate there's still plenty of bite left in the anthropomorphic CG menagerie.
reviews.author: Michael Rechtshaffen

reviews.text: Disney offers a decades-later correction to 'Song of the South,' in which rabbits and foxes have a chance to live together in relative harmony.
reviews.author: Peter Debruge

reviews.text: With its upfront themes of prejudice and diversity, and its release at a time in which society's biases are under the microscope, Zootopia may be one of the more fortuitously scheduled family entertainments in recent memory.
reviews.author: Robert Abele

synopsis: From the largest elephant to the smallest shrew, the city of Zootopia is a mammal metropolis where various animals live and thrive. When Judy Hopps (Ginnifer Goodwin) becomes the first rabbit to join the police force, she quickly learns how tough it is to enforce the law. Determined to prove herself, Judy jumps at the opportunity to solve a mysterious case. Unfortunately, that means working with Nick Wilde (Jason Bateman), a wily fox who makes her job even harder.
